awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Judicial Diversity and Appellate Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
By the end of 2016, over one-third of the federal appeals court bench was made up of women and over one-fifth were racial minorities. These figures stand in stark contrast to forty years earlier when the same appellate courts counted just one woman and three minority judges on active service.  This study uses social science theories and methods to examine how this historic demographic transformation of the federal bench affects deliberations, opinion writing, and organizational practices on the U.S. Circuit Courts of Appeals.  These findings will offer new and important insights on the intermediate appellate courts that serve a vital role in the administration of justice in the federal court system. 

Data are collected from published judicial opinions of the U.S. Courts of Appeals, biographical materials, and publicly available transcribed oral arguments, to test competing perspectives from social science theories about the effects of diversity on judicial decision making.  One set of theories focuses on the way in which differing perspectives of individuals linked to race and gender affect small group decision making. Another set of theories predicts that interactions during oral argument and subsequent citations to opinions will reflect on societal processes that generalize stereotypes about gender, race, status, and power. Finally, theories on gender and racial identity predict that women and minority judges will bring new approaches to oral argument, collaboration, and opinion drafting. To test these various expectations, this study leverages recent advances in linguistic software and automated methods of content analysis to produce a novel dataset of opinion content and extend an existing public resource, the Multi-User Database of U.S. Courts of Appeals Decisions.

por.por_cntn:
The study "Judicial Diversity and Appellate Decision Making" investigated how the historic diversification of the federal appeals courts under President Obama affected the process and outputs of judicial decisions. No other president to date has made a larger impact; nearly three-fourths of Obama?s appointees to the appellate bench were women and/or people of color.

The U.S. Courts of Appeals are important to study because they hear tens of thousands of cases every year and are effectively the court of last resort for most litigants in the federal judiciary. And because each circuit varies with respect to the number of judges and the norms and processes of decision making, these courts are also an ideal place to study how increased diversity affects organizations more broadly.  Some courts, like the Fourth Circuit, saw a dramatic transformation in the racial and gender diversity of their judges during this time period, while others, like the Eighth Circuit, were largely unchanged.

For the project, the research team read 2,880 appeals court cases and coded over 250 variables related to the judges, litigants, attorneys, procedural history, legal issues, outcomes, and subsequent citations to each case. In addition to collecting information on the legal authorities used in the reasoning of the majority opinion, we employed automated content analysis software to analyze the linguistic content and other attributes of opinions. For a subset of 150 cases from the Fourth, Eighth, and Ninth Circuits, the research team transcribed hours of oral arguments and recorded information about the participating attorneys and judges, as well as their exchanges, to allow for the study of gender dynamics in appellate oral argument. In addition, the team collected judicial performance measures and information on internal circuit procedures for each of the circuits across the time period of study. While analyses of many research questions are still in progress, our initial published findings provide some support for the premise that increased diversity contributes to more robust deliberations, depending on the size of the court.  We also found that majority opinions authored by women and people of color tended to be longer with more citations to legal authorities in the reasoning.  

One major achievement of the award was the creation of a series of datasets that can be used by scholars and practitioners across many disciplines (political science, law, public management, sociology). The project added the years 2009-2016 to the Multi-User Database on the U.S. Courts of Appeals, a widely-used database that has been awarded two previous NSF grants. The Multi-User Database has been used in numerous publications and dissertations since it was first released in the 1990s and updated in the early 2000s, and the extension we have completed will allow for future scholars to continue studying new questions about the federal appeals courts.  In addition, academics and practitioners will be able to utilize other newly created datasets about participants in appellate litigation, citations of majority opinions, judicial performance, circuit norms related to dissent, opinion content, and oral arguments.

Another broader impact of the project was that it supported training of a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students from the fields of political science, public policy, law, and public administration across four universities. Undergraduate students from the University of Louisville and the University of Georgia gained valuable experience presenting research findings at conferences and poster presentations.

Lastly, the dissemination of the research findings through public lectures, collaborations with law schools, and professional development activities sponsored by bar associations and other organizations will help increase understanding of how diversification of courts affects their processes and outputs.
